so i haven't made up my mind on this yet, but it's a pretty tricky topic. the lines between separation of church and state are getting blurred, and defining marriage has become a really touchy issue. on one hand, you have civil unions, which i think are a good alternative, but on the other hand, you have this whole idea of marriage as a sacrament that's deeply rooted in faith. if that's the case, people don't get tax breaks or any special treatment from the government just because they're baptized. so i'm inclined to think that marriage should be viewed as a civil union, a union between two people, without any government interference in what that union is or isn't.

the thing is, the fact that gay marriage is even a debate is a bit of a non-starter. if two people want to get married, or enter into a civil union, it's really no one's business but theirs. and if the states can come to a logical conclusion, then they should make it federal law. but a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage? that just seems like overkill. it's not a big enough issue to warrant changing the constitution.

it's not like it's some huge, earth-shattering cause that's worth amending the constitution over. it's just not that important. and to be honest, it's pretty ridiculous to try to define marriage in the constitution in the first place. i'm not even sure what to say to that.

I was raised in a Christian household, which has led to a somewhat mixed perspective on homosexuality for me. On one hand, I have many close gay friends, so it's hard for me to take a one-dimensional stance on the issue. While I don't necessarily agree with the lifestyle, I do think it should be legalized. I don't believe it's a matter for the federal government to decide; rather, each state should have the autonomy to make its own decision.

Considering the diversity of our country, with some states being more liberal and others more conservative, it's likely that each state will have its own stance on gay marriage. If you live in a state that has already legalized it, I don't think you should disagree with the decision, as you have chosen to reside there and should respect the local laws. My opinion is that homosexuals should have the same rights as heterosexuals, and therefore, the decision to legalize gay marriage should be left up to individual states.

I've already touched on this point, but to reiterate, I don't think the president should be able to impose their will on the entire country in regards to this issue. President Bush's ban on gay marriage doesn't sit well with me, as he doesn't live in every state and shouldn't dictate how each one runs itself. It would be more productive to let the states decide for themselves. Plus, with the president's term coming to an end soon, the issue will likely be revisited, and it's better to let each state make its own decision rather than having it change every time the presidency switches hands. It's the states that will have to live with the consequences of this decision, not the president.

Honestly, I'm finding it difficult to articulate my thoughts on this issue. Let me break it down for you. MySpace, like the internet in general, is a public platform where you post content for others to see. If you put something online, you have to accept that people will view it, including school officials. Even if you post under a pseudonym, they could still access it from their homes. In a situation where it might prevent a school shooting, I believe they have every right to do so. Their primary responsibility is to ensure student safety.

In fact, if school officials monitor Myspace to identify students engaging in prohibited activities, I think that's perfectly fine. It's their job to maintain a safe environment, and if that means keeping an eye on students' online behavior, so be it. Of course, there's a fine line between monitoring and invading students' privacy. However, if the monitoring leads to a safer school environment, I don't consider it an invasion of privacy.

It's a lot easier to express yourself in writing, but I'll try to summarize. Posting on Myspace is like sharing information with the public. If you're worried about getting in trouble for something you post, it's not unreasonable. Once something is online, it's there forever, and you can't take it back. This is something I'm cautious about, even in emails.

School officials have a responsibility to maintain a safe environment, and if that means monitoring Myspace or other online platforms, I'm okay with it. In fact, I've discussed this with a teacher of mine, and they feel the same way. They have to be prepared for potential threats, like lockdown drills in case of a terrorist attack. In a way, this incident was similar, as they were trying to prevent something like the Columbine shooting.

In short, I think school officials were justified in monitoring Myspace to ensure student safety. They were simply doing their job to prevent something bad from happening. That's all I wanted to say on the matter.

I guess I've been a bit quiet lately because I'm still trying to process my thoughts on the war. To be honest, my initial reaction after 9/11 was to support it. I was personally affected, and I felt like we needed to take action and show them that their actions wouldn't be tolerated. I think we went in there with a lot of emotions and anger, which clouded our judgment. We didn't really think about the long-term consequences or have a clear plan, which ultimately led to things not going as smoothly as we had hoped.

I've since changed my mind and I'm now firmly against the war. I don't think it's done anything to help the situation, and in fact, I think it's made things worse. The people over there are fighting amongst themselves, so us being there isn't really accomplishing anything. It's like they're more focused on fighting each other than working towards a common goal, and I just don't see how us being there is making a difference.

To be blunt, I've lost interest in what happens over there. I feel like we're just throwing our money and lives away for no reason. I've come to realize that war is a completely different beast when you're not the one waging it. The people over there have a completely different mindset, and I don't think they're looking to better their country, but rather get rid of us.

Looking back, I think we went in there on a mission of revenge rather than a rational, well-thought-out plan. I think President Bush was swept up in the emotional response to 9/11 and declared war on Iraq without a clear plan in place. At the time, I understood where he was coming from, but now I think we should have taken a more measured approach.

I don't think we could have just let things go after 9/11, but I do think we could have done a better job of planning and executing our strategy. There was a lack of unity and clear direction, and that's something that would have made a big difference. As it stands, I think we're just making things worse and hurting ourselves more than anyone else.

We're not the ones to change the people over there; they're going to be who they are, and we're not going to be able to fix that. I think we're just delaying the inevitable by staying there, and it's time for us to leave. We're not making enough progress, and once we do leave, things will likely collapse. I think we're just wasting our time and resources by staying, and it's time to cut our losses.

transformed_texts: i think the catholic church really needs to reevaluate its stance on certain issues. they're experiencing a decline in followers, and i believe it's because they're not very accepting of a lot of things. for instance, their rigid views on topics such as gay marriage, abortion, and birth control are quite outdated and may be driving people away. if they adapted to a more modern perspective, they might not lose their followers. many people are turning against the church due to its traditional views on these matters. those who disagree with the church on these subjects may not feel comfortable being part of a community where such views are strongly emphasized. this could lead to people leaving the church because they feel they're going against its teachings. i don't see why the church can't reconsider its stance on issues like female priests or priests being able to get married. it's possible that if they allowed priests to have personal relationships, it might not have changed the outcome, but it's worth exploring. however, the church's stance on these topics seems archaic, and it's hard to understand why they can't find a middle ground. they claim that priests are married to god and devoted to their faith, but they're essentially denying them a normal life with a family and loved ones, just like everyone else.

Honestly, I'll be the first to admit that I haven't fully given much thought to the issue of gay marriage. However, I'm not opposed to the idea in principle. I think people, regardless of their sexual orientation, shouldn't be held accountable for who they are. It's not like being gay is a choice that someone makes consciously. I believe people are born with their orientation, and it's not something they should be penalized for. To deny gay couples the right to marriage while allowing opposite-sex couples to do so just doesn't seem right to me.

On a deeper level, the idea that people's sexual orientation is not a choice seems obvious. Think about it - I was born straight, and others are born gay. It's not as if they have control over it. This lack of control means they shouldn't be held responsible for who they are.

In my opinion, the federal government shouldn't be involved in issues like this. It's not a matter of law or morality; it's simply about giving people the freedom to be who they are. I don't think it's fair to put people on a pedestal and imply they made a wrong decision or choice. Gay people aren't doing anything wrong; they're just existing and being themselves.

Frankly, I think the federal government is out of place here. It's not a matter of national security or moral values; it's simply a matter of people's personal lives. They shouldn't be intervened in or judged based on their orientation. It's who they are, and that's not something they should be punished for.

That's my take on the matter.

I'm in favor of legalizing gay marriage because there's no good reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but that's not true. It's like saying heads will never be tails - they're two sides of the same coin. While people may have different views on the matter, there are many civil rights at stake, such as property taxes, healthcare, and hospital visitation rights. If a gay couple is together, their partner shouldn't be denied the right to be with them in the hospital or visit them when they're sick.

The fact is, scientific studies have shown that gay couples have the same rates of success and satisfaction as heterosexual couples. They have the same factors that contribute to a happy relationship, such as communication, trust, and commitment. It's not about getting married in a church; it's about obtaining a marriage certificate, a legal document issued by the government.

If the government allows civil unions, it's hard to argue against granting marriage to gay couples. It's essentially segregation, separate but unequal. People worry about adoption issues and community concerns, but these concerns are unfounded. Gay couples can be just as good parents as heterosexual couples, and their children will face the same challenges in school and society.

In fact, some cities, like New York, have already implemented programs to support children of gay parents, such as special schools to protect them from bullying and harassment. It's not about the parents' sexual orientation; it's about the quality of care and parenting skills.

The federal government should take a more active role in this issue and make gay marriage legal in every state. The proposed amendment to ban gay marriage is hypocritical, considering the government's stance on other issues, such as stem cell research and the Pledge of Allegiance. It's unacceptable to enforce religious standards on an entire country while ignoring the moral and cultural diversity of its citizens.

Some people are anti-gay and anti-gay marriage because they believe that gay people are psychologically damaged or flawed. However, this is a misconception, as the American Psychological Association has refuted these claims. People should listen to institutions that conduct research and studies, rather than relying on popular opinion or cultural norms.

Well, I've got a bit of a soapbox moment here, so bear with me. As a pharmacy intern in a hospital over the summer, I've had some time to think about the whole issue of illegal substances. Now, just because something's on the list of forbidden substances doesn't mean it's inherently bad. Take it for what it's worth, I think it's fair to say that some illegal drugs have real benefits.

In fact, pharmacies like the one I'm working at use controlled substances like oxycodone, Vicodin, and Percocets all the time because they're proven to help people. And let's be real, if we're going to dismiss the potential benefits of marijuana because of its illegality, that's just a cop-out. We should be able to explore its medicinal uses without fear of judgment.

I'm not saying it's identical to alcohol, which can be abused and lead to all sorts of problems. But if we're honest, marijuana isn't exactly the same. If we could create a more nuanced view of marijuana, one that acknowledges its potential benefits, maybe people would use it more responsibly. After all, it's not like it's heroin or cocaine – it's not that toxic.

My point is, getting rid of the negative stigma surrounding marijuana might be the first step towards using it sensibly, especially for medicinal purposes. If we could move past the 'terrifying illicit substance' image, people might be more likely to use it in a way that's not detrimental to their health.

To be honest, I think the church has made some adjustments to fit into the 21st century. It's not as traditional as it used to be. Growing up, I used to go to church every Sunday, and it was a big deal - I'd get dressed up in matching outfits, including a cute little dress, shoes, and a purse. It was a big part of my private school experience, where I'd see all my friends every weekend. However, as I've gotten older, I've noticed some changes. They've introduced a shorter, 30-minute mass for teenagers, and it's become more casual. People often dress down, especially in the summer, and even families who run late still show up. It's become a more relaxed atmosphere, even during morning masses where people used to dress up. I've noticed that people now wear jeans and khakis, which is still nice, but it's a more casual vibe overall.

One thing that stands out to me is the shift in the church's atmosphere. I'm not familiar with the church's politics, but that's my observation. As for the recent scandals involving Catholic priests and pedophilia, I don't think allowing female priests or married priests would have prevented these incidents. There are married men who are still pedophiles, and it's not about the marriage or lack thereof - it's about the individual's attraction to young kids. When someone chooses to become a priest, it's their personal decision, and there are other faiths that allow their leaders to be married. If someone wants to practice their faith and be married, perhaps they should consider a different denomination.

I was asked to elaborate on my answer, and I think it boils down to the idea that pedophilia is more about genetics than environmental factors. People are born with their inclinations, and you can't change that through marriage or any other means. If the church knew about these issues and covered them up, that's a problem, but I don't think they were aware of everything in all cases. As for other thoughts on the Catholic Church, I don't have any other comments.

Honestly, at first, I wasn't entirely opposed to the premise, but looking back, I think the aftermath of the September 11th attacks was still a sensitive time, and we kind of got sidetracked into Iraq for reasons that weren't entirely genuine. The Bush administration initially linked the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, claiming Saddam Hussein had WMDs, but it's since been revealed that these claims were false.

To be frank, this really bothered me, and the Iraq war just gets my blood boiling. It seems to me that the Bush administration has lied to the American people and hasn't taken responsibility for it, even with Colin Powell admitting he wasn't convinced by the evidence he presented at the UN. That's a serious abuse of power and, in my opinion, an impeachable offense.

It's also disturbing to see the administration disregard the constitution and try to undermine it since 9/11. I think they came into office with the intention of going to war, despite the supposed pretext of WMDs and a connection to 9/11. In fact, it's been suggested that younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein due to his father's administration, and that he wanted to expand our energy supply, which is a pretty underhanded motive.

I think the war has dragged on for too long, but withdrawing now would have its own set of problems, as there's a risk that the country would descend into civil war and more people would lose their lives. The alternative seems to be a coalition of nearby nations, like Syria and Saudi Arabia, trying to stabilize the situation, but I'm not sure that's a good idea either. It's likely to create more problems in the long run, as Iraq's sovereignty becomes an increasingly contentious issue. The interim government is already showing signs of disintegration, and the Parliament is ineffective, with the Prime Minister having little control. The presence of radical elements, like Mugtada al-Sadr's party with 20 seats in Parliament, is causing a lot of friction in the political process.

To be honest, I'm struggling to articulate my concerns in a polite manner.

i was supposed to write something about my thoughts on the war in iraq, but it's really hard to form a coherent opinion on the topic. to be honest, i'm not even sure what's going on over there anymore. from what i understand, it started as a kind of get-back reaction because we thought iraq was behind the nine eleven attacks. but now it seems like we're just trying to set up a democracy in iraq, which sounds like a nice idea, but it's a lot harder to achieve than it sounds. 

i'm not really an expert on the war, but it seems like we're just causing more problems by being there. i mean, we're using a lot of resources, and it's making everyone upset. if we stay, we'll have to try and create a democracy, which will take a long time, and if we leave, they'll be mad at us for messing everything up. it's a tough spot to be in.

i've been trying to think about this for a while, but it's just really hard to wrap my head around it. i don't even know if i should be calling it a war anymore, since it wasn't even declared by congress. i think that's how it's supposed to work, right? 

i guess my opinion is that it's a pointless thing to stay in iraq, but at the same time, i feel bad for all the families whose kids are over there fighting. it's like, i want them to be safe, but at the same time, we're kind of destroying their country and culture. it's hard to say what's the right thing to do. 

i feel like the war is going to go on for a long time, and it's just going to get worse and worse. it's already making us look bad, and it's just causing more and more problems. it's hard to know what to think, but i guess that's my two cents on the matter.

i think the whole thing would be a lot simpler if we just declared it a war and got it over with, but that's not how it works. it's like, we're trying to turn iraq into a second u.s., but that's not going to work. it's just going to make things worse, and it's going to fuel the al-qaeda thing even more. i don't know, it's just a mess.

anyway, that's my attempt at forming an opinion on the war in iraq. i'm not exactly sure what to think, but i hope that's a start.

To be honest, I have strong reservations about the government declaring something as legal or not. I believe it's more the domain of churches to decide these matters, given the separation of church and state as outlined in the constitution. This principle is crystal clear, and any attempt to impose power over it would essentially defy the constitution's written words. 

In my opinion, those trying to make it illegal are essentially favoring one church's beliefs over another. The fact that most Catholics and Christians don't support it, except in a few areas, speaks volumes. It doesn't seem right for the government to dictate what churches can and can't make illegal.

The separation of church and state has been a cornerstone of the constitution, allowing for religious tolerance in the United States. Proposing an amendment to address this issue seems counterintuitive, as it would contradict the constitution's existing provisions. Furthermore, it would likely be the only amendment restricting individual freedoms rather than limiting government power.

I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved in this matter. The president's push for the amendment appears to be driven by personal beliefs, which raises the concern that he's favoring one religion over others. Ultimately, the decision should rest with the churches, not the government or its officials. There's little justification for the amendment beyond personal views, and I fail to see how it would positively impact the economy or society. In fact, it could potentially have a positive effect on society, so I don't think there's a valid reason to pursue it.

I've expressed my main points, so I'll leave it at that.

Okay, I was thinking about the war in Iraq, and I believe the government was less than honest with the American people about the reasons for invading the country before going in. It seemed like there was an attempt to link the invasion to the 9/11 attacks, which wasn't entirely accurate. The government played on the emotions of the American people in the aftermath of 9/11 to justify the invasion, and it began in 2003.

To start, I'm not a fan of war, especially when it's a preemptive strike. I think the war in Iraq has a lot of parallels with the Vietnam War. The government should have learned from past mistakes and not repeated them. A huge number of American soldiers have lost their lives, which is tragic and unacceptable.

When the US invaded Iraq, they removed the country's government without being prepared for the aftermath or the power vacuum that would follow. It's like trying to impose a democratic government without considering the potential consequences. They were trying to do the same thing in Vietnam, pushing out Communists and establishing democracy.

However, the US government should have known that this would be a long and challenging process. It's not something that can be achieved easily, especially when you're fighting an insurgency rather than a conventional army. You're fighting ordinary citizens who are resisting the occupation, making it extremely difficult to put them down.

I think the government rushed into war without being adequately prepared for the outcome, and that's been a major issue. If we're going to go to war, we need to plan for all possible outcomes. The government failed to do this, and we're still dealing with the consequences. Many American troops are still in Iraq, and we're still trying to train the Iraqi military and police forces to take control of their country.

In my opinion, the US government tried to deceive the American people by making it seem like the invasion would be a quick and successful operation. However, it's not that simple. Implementing a new form of government takes time, and it's not something that can be achieved overnight. We're naive to think it would be easy, especially when we consider our own country's history with democracy.

The war in Iraq is a complicated issue, and there's no easy solution. If I had to vote in the 2004 presidential election, one of my reservations about voting for George Bush was that he would finish what he started. However, it's hard to abandon a country after being involved for so long, especially when we've taken away their government and way of life.

On the other hand, it's impossible to ignore the number of American casualties and the risk of further losses. We need to consider the cost of continuing the war and whether it's worth it for the sake of a free democratic Iraq. If we're making the case that Iraq needs democracy, why aren't we doing the same for other countries? I think the real reason is the oil issue and controlling resources. The US government's decisions are often driven by self-interest and a desire for power.

In conclusion, I just hope that the war in Iraq ends soon and that peace is restored. However, I'm not optimistic about the situation, and it's likely that it will take a long time to resolve.

Well, let me get this straight - I'm all for gay marriage, I've always been. It's a personal choice, and I think it's ridiculous that people are still debating this. With all the evidence that shows it's not just a social construct, but something that could be biological, it's inhumane to deny people rights because of something they can't control.

I'm not sure why the government and politicians are even involved in this. It's a personal issue, not a state or national concern. I mean, take my neighborhood for instance - there are at least two openly gay couples living there, and they're just like any other family. They walk their dogs, go about their daily lives, and what's the difference? I think it's absurd that President Bush is trying to dictate what marriage means and imposing his own interpretation on the rest of us.

From what I've read and heard, there's a growing body of evidence that suggests there's a chemical component to being gay, something that's not just a product of upbringing or environment. It's not like being gay is a choice, it's a natural part of who people are. So, I just don't get why it's such a big deal.

It's not like straight couples need to jump through hoops to get married. If a guy and a girl want to get hitched, they can just elope in Vegas and nobody bats an eye, but if two gay people want to do the same, it's front-page news. I think marriage should be a private, personal thing, not something that's splashed all over the national news.

No, I don't think so.

Well, I'm here to give you a reality check - when you post something online, it's essentially public domain. You can't expect your personal opinions or actions to remain private. As someone who's dealt with this firsthand as a resident advisor, I can attest to the fact that anything you put out there can shape people's perceptions of you. This can be particularly problematic when you're discussing sensitive or serious topics like violence or shootings. Someone, somewhere, will inevitably stumble upon it and react.

The internet is a vast, open space that's accessible to everyone, including your friends and acquaintances on social media platforms. Whether it's a bulletin on Myspace or a post on Facebook, it's not just a school or institution that's exposed to it - it's the entire online community. If something serious enough is posted, it can put people on high alert, and as you can imagine, schools and institutions can't just ignore these warnings.

It's a delicate line to walk because, on the one hand, some people might be joking or engaging in a social experiment, while others might be genuinely expressing their thoughts or concerns. Take the recent incident at our school, for example, where someone overheard a comment and reported it, leading to a deeper investigation. It turned out that a student had posted some concerning content on their social media profiles that they never intended to be taken seriously, but in hindsight, it became a serious issue.

When you post something online, you should be aware that there's no such thing as true online privacy. If you don't want your thoughts or actions to be public knowledge, it's best not to post them in the first place. You can't control how people interpret your online presence, but you can control what you put out there. School officials, for instance, shouldn't be friending their students on social media or snooping through their profiles - that's just not their place.

However, if something concerning is brought to their attention, they have a responsibility to take it seriously and act accordingly. It's a different story if they're monitoring private communications like phone conversations or texts without consent. But if it's something that's publicly available, they can't just ignore it.

As a residential advisor, I wouldn't even think of friending my residents on social media, not because I'm concerned about their online activities, but because I don't want to be privy to that information. That's not my place, and I'd rather not have to deal with the potential consequences. So, to sum it up, be mindful of what you post online because it can have real-world implications.

I'm starting to feel like the war has dragged on for far too long. Initially, the idea seemed to be a good one – to bring democracy to a country in need. However, it seems like we've lost sight of that original goal. Instead, it feels like we're fighting for the sake of being a global superpower, just to prove a point. I'm also concerned that the real motives behind the war were questionable from the start, considering George Bush's father's past conflicts with Saddam Hussein.

If our goal was to bring democracy to a country with an unfair political system, that would have been a justifiable reason, as long as there weren't any personal agendas involved. However, I think we achieved our initial objective in the first few months, and that was a significant statement in itself.

The fact that the war has dragged on for over a year, or even several years, is just too much. I believe our purpose has been slowly eroded over time, and it's now more about being at war for the sake of being at war. We're not looking for a decisive end or a victory; we just don't want to lose face.

I think it's time for us to call it quits. The Iraqi government will eventually have to take care of itself, and our continued involvement is just draining our economy. We're spending billions of dollars on a war that's lost its purpose, while we have our own problems to address, such as poverty and internal issues like public roads, schools, and healthcare. It seems like a waste of resources to be spending that money on a war that's not achieving its original goal.

It's astounding to think that we're spending billions and billions of dollars on a war that's not in our long-term budget. We have our own problems to solve at home, and it's time for us to focus on those. Our citizens are dying in a foreign country, and it's just not worth it.

I wanted to clarify a point, but I'm not sure if I should even bring it up. Apparently, someone online discovered that there was a reason certain information was being kept from the public. Okay, so here's my question: if you post stuff on the internet, like on Myspace, for instance, you have to accept that a lot of people are going to see it. I mean, if you want to be friends with someone on Myspace, you basically give them permission to view your profile, right? So, anytime you put info on the internet, you have to understand that it's out there for anyone to see.

It's a bit of a tough situation because, on one hand, you can't have someone sitting around all day monitoring everyone's profiles to prevent something bad from happening, but on the other hand, it's like, what if they're just looking for evidence of someone doing something wrong? It's not clear-cut. I mean, I don't think it's right to have someone's job just to snoop through people's profiles, but I guess it depends on the circumstances.

Personally, I don't have a Myspace account, but I do have a Facebook one. It's a bit unsettling to think that there are people out there who can see things about me just by looking at my profile. I saw this thing on TV once where this guy was showing how easy it is to get information about someone online. He went onto this girl's Myspace profile and got her screen name in like a minute and started talking to her on instant messenger. It's pretty scary.

It's hard to balance the fact that you want to be able to communicate with your friends online, but at the same time, you don't want to put too much information out there that could be used against you. I've noticed that some of my classmates can IM me without even knowing my screen name, which is a bit unnerving. They know a lot about me from my profile, including my class schedule and what my friends are like. I've tried to limit what I put up, but it's a tricky balance to strike.

I was talking to my roommate about this, and she said that in her high school, students were banned from having Myspace accounts. I'm not sure how the school had the right to do that, and it seemed a bit unfair. I'm not sure if that's a real privacy issue, but it did strike me as strange.

I struggled with whether to bring up the Iraq War topic, but I guess I have to eventually. I feel a bit hypocritical talking about it, as I don't want to jump on the bandwagon of people who claim they were against it from the start. However, it's not really a crucial issue anymore, as everyone except the Bush administration seems to agree that it was a bad idea. Looking at the recent polls, it's clear that the majority of the world population thinks so, with around 75-80% of the global population, 80% of Iraqis, and 70% of US troops in Iraq all sharing this sentiment. It's hard to argue with the fact that the conflict has been a disaster since before our involvement, and now it's a challenge to find a solution that won't make things worse.

I believe the underlying issue is the deep cultural divide between the US and Middle Eastern states, which makes it difficult for our administration to understand the local perspective. It's naive to think we can impose democracy on an area where it's not naturally embraced. While Saddam was a bad guy, we should have carefully weighed the pros and cons before invading. The situation has turned into a quagmire, and I don't see a reason for us to stay any longer. I'm not convinced by the administration's arguments about the potential problems that might arise from our withdrawal, and I'd love to hear a legitimate reason to stay.

If the administration plans to withdraw gradually over a year or more, I wouldn't have a major issue with that. However, I just can't see the justification for prolonging our presence. It's even more ironic that 80% of Iraqis think we should be gone within a year, with a quarter of them wanting us to leave immediately. These are the people we're trying to help, and they're essentially telling us to leave. I think they might know better than us, and at least if we ask them and they say yes, we can't blame them if things go wrong. If we decide to help out after that, we'll at least be seen as the lesser of two evils, rather than the enemy in the Middle East.

you know, i think gender discrimination is still an issue in the US.  it's not just a women's problem, though - it's more complex than that.  i believe it's often tied to the specific industry or work environment, and how long it's traditionally been male-dominated.  for instance, in business, women face a 'glass ceiling' where they might have all the qualifications for a job, but are overlooked for promotions due to ingrained societal attitudes. 

the same can be said for men in certain industries, like fashion, where being a stay-at-home parent is often viewed as unusual and not masculine.  it's a common stereotype that men should be the breadwinners, and people look down on them if they choose to take on more domestic responsibilities.  this can be tough for men who want to be involved in childcare and support their families, but are judged for their choices. 

in fashion, there's also the issue of men being taken seriously if they're interested in it as a career.  people often doubt their credibility because of societal expectations around masculinity and style.  it's like, how can you truly understand fashion if you're a guy?  the same goes for men who don't fit the typical mold of masculinity.

societal attitudes and mindsets are hard to change, and it's a slow process.  we've made progress, but it's still a work in progress.  women are breaking into leadership positions and being accepted in the business world, and more men are choosing to be stay-at-home dads.  as we continue to push for change, it's essential to promote the qualities and strengths of those who are often stereotyped or overlooked.  we need to do this in a way that's not pushy or aggressive, but rather by showcasing their abilities and potential. 

it's all about finding a balance and promoting acceptance, rather than forcing it.  we're at a good point where it's starting to become more mainstream, but change takes time.  i'm not sure what more we can do, as it seems like we're already seeing progress.  it's also worth noting that people from different backgrounds and with varying levels of education can face discrimination, not just based on gender but also on other factors like socioeconomic status, education level, or geographical location.

It seems that many people misunderstand the recent changes to the law regarding this substance.  To clarify, it was decriminalized, not fully legalized. In other words, it's no longer a serious crime, but rather a minor offense, akin to a traffic ticket. You might get cited and fined without facing the full penalties of arrest and prosecution.

One issue people often worry about when it comes to decriminalization is the potential long-term consequences, such as difficulties in job interviews and other professional situations. These repercussions can still linger even after decriminalization. However, some argue that the costs associated with arresting and processing individuals, including courtroom appearances and public defender fees, can be substantial.

From a budgetary perspective, many municipalities struggle to justify the expense of enforcing this law. Even if it would lead to significant cost savings, some communities may not be willing to make this change, especially if they're strongly opposed to the substance.

On the other hand, places like Denver, where there's a more open-minded attitude, might find it reasonable to decriminalize it. As a result, they could potentially redirect funds to more pressing needs, such as public education, social programs for the elderly, and services for the homeless.

It's essential to consider the financial implications, as well as other factors, when discussing this topic. While marijuana shouldn't be allowed to be ubiquitous, the financial element does play a role in the decision-making process. Some people might be concerned that if it were fully legalized, it could lead to widespread use and potentially problematic behaviors, like driving under the influence. However, it's also true that many people view marijuana as taboo, and making it widely available might be awkward for some.

In general, both marijuana and alcohol have their negative effects, but they can impact people differently. Some might be more susceptible to the lifestyle consequences of marijuana use, while others may be more affected by its impact on motor skills. Ultimately, everyone's reaction to substances is unique, and it's difficult to make broad generalizations.

so i haven't made up my mind on this yet, but it's a pretty tricky topic. the lines between separation of church and state are getting blurred, and defining marriage has become a really touchy issue. on one hand, you have civil unions, which i think are a good alternative, but on the other hand, you have this whole idea of marriage as a sacrament that's deeply rooted in faith. if that's the case, people don't get tax breaks or any special treatment from the government just because they're baptized. so i'm inclined to think that marriage should be viewed as a civil union, a union between two people, without any government interference in what that union is or isn't.

the thing is, the fact that gay marriage is even a debate is a bit of a non-starter. if two people want to get married, or enter into a civil union, it's really no one's business but theirs. and if the states can come to a logical conclusion, then they should make it federal law. but a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage? that just seems like overkill. it's not a big enough issue to warrant changing the constitution.

it's not like it's some huge, earth-shattering cause that's worth amending the constitution over. it's just not that important. and to be honest, it's pretty ridiculous to try to define marriage in the constitution in the first place. i'm not even sure what to say to that.

I was raised in a Christian household, which has led to a somewhat mixed perspective on homosexuality for me. On one hand, I have many close gay friends, so it's hard for me to take a one-dimensional stance on the issue. While I don't necessarily agree with the lifestyle, I do think it should be legalized. I don't believe it's a matter for the federal government to decide; rather, each state should have the autonomy to make its own decision.

Considering the diversity of our country, with some states being more liberal and others more conservative, it's likely that each state will have its own stance on gay marriage. If you live in a state that has already legalized it, I don't think you should disagree with the decision, as you have chosen to reside there and should respect the local laws. My opinion is that homosexuals should have the same rights as heterosexuals, and therefore, the decision to legalize gay marriage should be left up to individual states.

I've already touched on this point, but to reiterate, I don't think the president should be able to impose their will on the entire country in regards to this issue. President Bush's ban on gay marriage doesn't sit well with me, as he doesn't live in every state and shouldn't dictate how each one runs itself. It would be more productive to let the states decide for themselves. Plus, with the president's term coming to an end soon, the issue will likely be revisited, and it's better to let each state make its own decision rather than having it change every time the presidency switches hands. It's the states that will have to live with the consequences of this decision, not the president.

Honestly, I'm finding it difficult to articulate my thoughts on this issue. Let me break it down for you. MySpace, like the internet in general, is a public platform where you post content for others to see. If you put something online, you have to accept that people will view it, including school officials. Even if you post under a pseudonym, they could still access it from their homes. In a situation where it might prevent a school shooting, I believe they have every right to do so. Their primary responsibility is to ensure student safety.

In fact, if school officials monitor Myspace to identify students engaging in prohibited activities, I think that's perfectly fine. It's their job to maintain a safe environment, and if that means keeping an eye on students' online behavior, so be it. Of course, there's a fine line between monitoring and invading students' privacy. However, if the monitoring leads to a safer school environment, I don't consider it an invasion of privacy.

It's a lot easier to express yourself in writing, but I'll try to summarize. Posting on Myspace is like sharing information with the public. If you're worried about getting in trouble for something you post, it's not unreasonable. Once something is online, it's there forever, and you can't take it back. This is something I'm cautious about, even in emails.

School officials have a responsibility to maintain a safe environment, and if that means monitoring Myspace or other online platforms, I'm okay with it. In fact, I've discussed this with a teacher of mine, and they feel the same way. They have to be prepared for potential threats, like lockdown drills in case of a terrorist attack. In a way, this incident was similar, as they were trying to prevent something like the Columbine shooting.

In short, I think school officials were justified in monitoring Myspace to ensure student safety. They were simply doing their job to prevent something bad from happening. That's all I wanted to say on the matter.

I guess I've been a bit quiet lately because I'm still trying to process my thoughts on the war. To be honest, my initial reaction after 9/11 was to support it. I was personally affected, and I felt like we needed to take action and show them that their actions wouldn't be tolerated. I think we went in there with a lot of emotions and anger, which clouded our judgment. We didn't really think about the long-term consequences or have a clear plan, which ultimately led to things not going as smoothly as we had hoped.

I've since changed my mind and I'm now firmly against the war. I don't think it's done anything to help the situation, and in fact, I think it's made things worse. The people over there are fighting amongst themselves, so us being there isn't really accomplishing anything. It's like they're more focused on fighting each other than working towards a common goal, and I just don't see how us being there is making a difference.

To be blunt, I've lost interest in what happens over there. I feel like we're just throwing our money and lives away for no reason. I've come to realize that war is a completely different beast when you're not the one waging it. The people over there have a completely different mindset, and I don't think they're looking to better their country, but rather get rid of us.

Looking back, I think we went in there on a mission of revenge rather than a rational, well-thought-out plan. I think President Bush was swept up in the emotional response to 9/11 and declared war on Iraq without a clear plan in place. At the time, I understood where he was coming from, but now I think we should have taken a more measured approach.

I don't think we could have just let things go after 9/11, but I do think we could have done a better job of planning and executing our strategy. There was a lack of unity and clear direction, and that's something that would have made a big difference. As it stands, I think we're just making things worse and hurting ourselves more than anyone else.

We're not the ones to change the people over there; they're going to be who they are, and we're not going to be able to fix that. I think we're just delaying the inevitable by staying there, and it's time for us to leave. We're not making enough progress, and once we do leave, things will likely collapse. I think we're just wasting our time and resources by staying, and it's time to cut our losses.
